awd_titl_txt: Design of DNA Origami Machines and Mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration:
This research award provides funding for the development of a systematic design framework for nanoscale machines and mechanisms using DNA origami nanotechnology.  DNA origami enables construction of two and three-dimensional nanoscale shapes with unprecedented geometric complexity via molecular self-assembly. The majority of DNA origami research focuses on assembly of static 2D or 3D structures.  The goal of this work is to incorporate functional dynamic parts with directed motion into the DNA origami design toolbox.  To achieve this goal, a kinematics approach will be implemented to design DNA origami machines and mechanisms that are comprised of links and joints, similar to macroscale machines.   A catalogue of various DNA origami links and joints will be designed and fabricated, and their mechanical properties will be characterized experimentally and by molecular simulation.  These links and joints will be implemented in the design of prototype mechanisms for proof-of-principle studies.  A new theory called projection kinematics will be developed to evaluate the three-dimensional motion of these prototype mechanisms from two-dimensional electron microscopy snapshots.  To facilitate future application of DNA origami machines, a computer aided design and simulation program will be developed that facilitates conceptual mechanism design and automates the integration of DNA origami links and joints from the previously developed part catalogues.   

If successful, this research will greatly advance the fields of DNA nanotechnology, nanoscale design, and nano-robotics.  The machines and mechanisms developed in this work together with nanoactuators and controllers will enable design of future nanorobots for applications in numerous fields such as self-assembling computers and chemical compounds, nano-manufacturing, molecular transport in bio-reactors, and drug delivery.  This work also opens the door for applying kinematic design to DNA nanotechnology.  The computer design automation software developed in this research will greatly facilitate the widespread use of DNA origami mechanisms and machines.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The focus of this research project was to develop an engineering design framework for DNA origami nanostructures. DNA origami is an emerging technology to design nanoscale structures via molecular self-assembly. This approach has enabled the fabrication of nanostructures with astounding geometric complexity almost similar to a 3D printing design space, but DNA origami structures have typical dimensions ranging from ten up to a few hundred nanometers. The majority of prior research has focused on the design of static nanostructures that are designed to maintain a rigid shape, and a few recent efforts have developed some reconfigurable structures with relatively simple motion. Our research project established and demonstrated a design approach for dynamic DNA origami nanostructures that parallels the design of macroscopic engineering machines or robots. We developed DNA origami joints that mimic hinges with rotational motion, sliders with linear motion, or combinations thereof. Following a machine design approach we demonstrated the ability to assemble these joints into mechanisms with complex 2D or 3D motion.

In particular, we designed DNA origami versions of crank-sliders, which are the same mechanism used in many steam engines; extended scissor linkages, which are similar to a scissor lift mechanism; and Bennett Linkages, which have been used for the design of deployable macroscopic systems. We also established fundamental advances in programming the self-assembly process to enable the design of multi-component structures where component can fit together following a detailed assembly plan. Our overall mechanical design framework is illustrated in Figure 1. We have also developed a number of methods for controlling the motion of these DNA origami mechanisms and machines that allow direct actuation of motion.

Going forward we aim to use these DNA origami machines as controllable devices for applications in the study of biological systems, for direct manipulation of other objects in nanomanufacturing systems, or as responsive devices for biomedical applications such as multiplexed biosensing or targeted drug delivery.

We have also leveraged this research for a number of broader educational and outreach impacts. Given that the focus of our research is to relate DNA origami nanotechnology to classical machine and robot design, it is uniquely suited to introduce advanced concepts such as self-assembly, DNA sequence design, and biomolecule mechanics to students ranging from undergraduates to elementary school. Our research team has supported a number of undergraduate researchers from mechanical engineering, chemical engineering, and biomedical engineering. Multiple of these undergraduate researchers engaged in Ohio State University’s “Translating Engineering to K through 8” program, where they collaborate with the faculty advisors, high school teachers, and other undergraduate students to develop design challenges that are then presented at a local elementary school, KIPP academy. The two faculty members involved in the project have also regularly presented this research through summer programs organized by the Minority Engineering Program at OSU designed to introduce incoming freshman, high school students, or middle school students to engineering and advanced research. Finally, the principal investigator of this project started a biomolcular design team, called OhioMOD, that is an inter-disciplinary team of 6 - 10 undergraduate students that compete yearly in the biomolecular design competition, BIOMOD (biomod.net). Throughout the project over 20 undergraduate students have participated, and as part of the project the team develops a youtube video to describe the research to the general public. Combined, our teams’ vidoes have been viewed over 2,000 times on youtube.

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2016
Modified by: Carlos E Castro
